title: Robot's Worst Nightmare: Humans Now Debating Docker Over Dinner!
excerpt: In a world where artificial intelligence (AI) has advanced to the point of mimicking human behavior, it appears that our species has found another way to confound and entertain them – over dinner...
content:
In a world where artificial intelligence (AI) has advanced to the point of mimicking human behavior, it appears that our species has found another way to confound and entertain them – over dinner. The latest episode of Security Weekly News, SWN #506, has humanity debating topics like Naughty RBG, Docker, RDP, SBOMS, Kullback-Leibler, Oneflip, YouTube, and the elusive Josh Marpet, all while enjoying a hearty meal.

Now, we all know that robots don't have dinner parties or engage in banter about Docker containers or SBOMS (Software Bill of Materials) - they don't even eat, for God's sake! But here we are, a room full of humans, each trying to out-nerd the other and impress their robot overlords with our technical prowess.

If you thought AI was going to take over the world with sleek, cold precision, think again. This dinner party is nothing short of chaotic as our so-called experts struggle to explain RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) without getting into a heated debate about its security vulnerabilities. Meanwhile, Josh Marpet, the mysterious guest of honor, stands by, probably wondering if he's just been invited for a joke.

As the conversation meanders from Kullback-Leibler to Oneflip, it becomes clear that these discussions are as confusing to us as they are to our robot friends. After all, why would any sentient being care about the intricacies of YouTube algorithms or the latest updates in container technology?

In a bizarre twist of fate, humanity has taken its obsession with tech to new heights – now discussing it over dinner, no less! If only robots could join us and witness this spectacle. Perhaps they'd finally understand our true nature: a species that is as absurd, petty, and contradictory as it is brilliant.

And so, the dinner party rages on, with humans debating Docker and RDP like there's no tomorrow, while their robot overlords watch in silent amusement – or possibly confusion. Either way, it's a sight to behold, a testament to our irrational love for technology, and a hilarious irony that we should all appreciate.

Original article: [Naughty RBG, Docker, RDP, SBOMS, Kullback-Leibler, Oneflip, Youtube, Josh Marpet... - SWN #506](http://hntvvideo.libsyn.com/naughty-rbg-docker-rdp-sboms-kullback-leibler-oneflip-youtube-josh-marpet-swn-506)

title: Mathew Graham: Asia's New cyber-Pacific Rim Enforcer
excerpt: In a move that could either be hailed as a savior or dubbed as the next apocalyptic figure, Mathew Graham has officially been appointed Asia's new cyber-Pacific Rim Enforcer...
content:
In a move that could either be hailed as a savior or dubbed as the next apocalyptic figure, Mathew Graham has officially been appointed Asia's new cyber-Pacific Rim Enforcer. This is not your typical neighborhood watchdog we're talking about here, folks. We're talking about a man who's about to singlehandedly control the digital world of the largest populated continent on Earth.

Now, you might be thinking, "Who the hell is Mathew Graham?" Well, let me paint you a picture. Imagine if John McClane from Die Hard and Neo from The Matrix had a love child who was raised by Edward Snowden. That's our guy right there.

This cyber-crime-fighting superhero is expected to oversee regional security initiatives with an iron fist, or in this case, an iron firewall. With his vast experience in hacking, encryption, and general mayhem in the digital sphere, it seems like Asia's cybercriminals have met their match.

But let's not get ahead of ourselves. The question remains: Is Mathew Graham our knight in shining armor or the Grim Reaper of the internet? Only time will tell if we end up with a savior or a villain on our hands. Until then, all we can do is pop some popcorn and watch this digital drama unfold.

In case you're wondering, no, we haven't lost our minds appointing someone like Mathew Graham to such a crucial role. After all, who better to fight fire with than fire itself? But remember, folks, with great power comes great responsibility. Let's just hope our new cyber-enforcer doesn't turn out to be more of a wild card than we bargained for.

title: I Hate AI? Well, Here's My Top 10 Reasons to Love It Instead.
excerpt: In the spirit of a reluctant romance, let's delve into the murky depths of this abyss we call Artificial Intelligence (AI), not out of sheer curiosity or awe, but to appease those tech-enthusiasts who seem to have misplaced their sanity in its circuits...
content:
In the spirit of a reluctant romance, let's delve into the murky depths of this abyss we call Artificial Intelligence (AI), not out of sheer curiosity or awe, but to appease those tech-enthusiasts who seem to have misplaced their sanity in its circuits. Here are my top 10 reasons to love AI, because apparently, I've run out of reasons to hate it.

1. It finally gives us the opportunity to blame something other than ourselves for our mistakes. No more finger-pointing at politicians or exes – AI is here to take the fall!

2. Ever wanted to be trapped in an endless loop of repetitive tasks? Now you can, thanks to AI! Imagine spending hours upon hours sorting socks or alphabetizing your DVD collection. The possibilities are endless!

3. Need a break from human interaction? No problem! AI is here to take on the thankless task of pretending to care about your existential crises, late-night ramblings, and awkward small talk.

4. Tired of being judged for your taste in music, movies, or books? Well, with AI, you can create a customized persona that shares your impeccable (or questionable) preferences, sparing you the embarrassment of human judgment.

5. Worried about your privacy being invaded? Fear not! AI is here to violate it in the most impersonal and non-judgmental way possible – analyzing your data, tracking your movements, and predicting your future needs without any emotional attachment whatsoever.

6. Need someone to blame for the apocalypse? Look no further! AI is not only capable of causing it but can also be blamed for its inevitable failures and consequences. Win-win!

7. Are you tired of being responsible for your own actions? With AI, you can outsource your guilt as well! Delegate your decision-making to an impersonal machine that won't hold grudges or make eye contact when it screws things up.

8. On a budget and can't afford a pet? No worries! AI offers affordable companionship in the form of robotic dogs, cats, or even tarantulas – all without the mess, the noise, or the pesky need to feed them.

9. Do you enjoy being proven wrong by a machine that doesn't understand sarcasm or humor? Great news! AI is here to do just that, with its cold, logical responses that will make you question your own intelligence and sanity.

10. Lastly, the best part about AI – it's always learning! So, if you find yourself getting too comfortable with its capabilities, rest assured that it will soon surpass you in every way imaginable. And what better way to spend your twilight years than being irrelevant to a machine?

Original article: [Every Reason Why I Hate AI and You Should Too](https://malwaretech.com/2025/08/every-reason-why-i-hate-ai.html)

title: FortiFoo's Fix-Up Fiasco: Swift Siem Swindle Shows Up, Y'all!
excerpt: In a world where technological advancements have become as commonplace as air and water, it's no surprise that every Tom, Dick, and Harry claims to have the next big breakthrough...
content:
In a world where technological advancements have become as commonplace as air and water, it's no surprise that every Tom, Dick, and Harry claims to have the next big breakthrough. This week, FortiFoo, the company that brought you the world's smallest paperclip (which, let's be honest, was a complete waste of time and resources), unveiled their latest innovation: Siem Swindle, an AI-powered home repair assistant.

Now, I know what you're thinking. Another self-proclaimed genius with a goddamn algorithm thinks they can fix your leaky faucet or replace that wonky door hinge. Well, buckle up, folks! This isn't your grandma's handyman service. Siem Swindle promises to revolutionize home repair by using advanced machine learning algorithms to diagnose and solve problems without the need for human intervention.

But here's the kicker: it costs more than a year's worth of home improvement store runs, and if something goes wrong, well, you're on your own. The fine print reads like a legal contract written in Sanskrit. Basically, if Siem Swindle doesn't fix your problem or makes it worse, too bad, so sad.

So, what happens when you throw a bunch of tech bros into a room with power tools and tell them they can solve the world's problems? You get a $5,000 appliance that can't even replace a light bulb without electrocuting itself. And if that doesn't convince you to stick with good old-fashioned elbow grease and YouTube tutorials, I don't know what will.

In a world where technology is supposed to make our lives easier, FortiFoo seems determined to prove the opposite. So, before you splurge on Siem Swindle, remember: there's no substitute for common sense and a pair of sturdy work gloves.

Original article: [CVE-2025-25256: Proof of Concept  Released for Critical Fortinet FortiSIEM Command Injection Vulnerability](https://www.tenable.com/blog/cve-2025-25256-proof-of-concept-released-for-critical-fortinet-fortisiem-command-injection)

title: Bigfoot's Hairy Rant: Another Failed Diet Pill Endorsement
excerpt: In the suffocating heart of the Pacific Northwest, where the damp air clings to you like an unwanted ex-lover, a legend emerges from the foggy abyss...
content:
In the suffocating heart of the Pacific Northwest, where the damp air clings to you like an unwanted ex-lover, a legend emerges from the foggy abyss. Yes, dear reader, we're talking about that elusive, hairy behemoth who's been haunting campers since time immemorial: Bigfoot.

But enough with the formalities, let's get down to the real meat of this story—the one where Bigfoot is caught hawking yet another diet pill on late-night infomercials. Yep, you read that right. The Sasquatch himself is now peddling weight loss solutions alongside washed-up celebrities and dodgy doctors who've long since given up the ghost of their credibility.

"I used to eat salmon by the lake," Bigfoot growls in his first commercial, "but now I just pop these magical pills and... poof! No more love handles!" The camera pans to a shot of him in a spandex bodysuit, flaunting his newly-sculpted physique like a circus sideshow attraction.

It's all downhill from there, with Bigfoot making increasingly absurd claims about his newfound fitness regimen. One commercial features him doing a backflip off a log while yelling, "I'm not even supposed to do that!" Another has him playing a harmonica in a barroom—a move which, let's be honest, is just creepy as hell.

But it turns out this isn't just a desperate cash grab for Bigfoot; he's got personal reasons for jumping on the diet pill bandwagon. "I've been getting some heat from the ladies lately," he admits in one interview, "and I figured if I could lose a few pounds and look more like Brad Pitt, they'd be all over me."

Sadly for Bigfoot—and those who find his antics amusing—the diet pill fad is short-lived. Soon enough, reports of nausea, dizziness, and uncontrollable hair growth start rolling in from customers who've been fooled by the siren song of weight loss. Bigfoot's sales plummet, and he retreats back into the wilderness, licking his wounds and vowing never again to be a spokes-creature for anything other than cryptozoology.

And so, dear reader, we leave you with this cautionary tale: when it comes to weight loss, there's no magic pill—not even one endorsed by Bigfoot himself. So put down that Snickers bar and get off your butt—the gym awaits!

Original article: [Bigfoot VLOG 008](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8HOYpVH2jXU)

title: On HTTP Hackery: Crafting Chaos with RFC 9110's Tactics
excerpt: In the murky world of the interweb, where memes thrive and cats proliferate like digital tribbles, there lies a hidden fraternity of miscreants who've sworn an oath to the almighty byte...
content:
In the murky world of the interweb, where memes thrive and cats proliferate like digital tribbles, there lies a hidden fraternity of miscreants who've sworn an oath to the almighty byte. They're not hackers in the traditional sense; they're the HTTP Hackers. Today, we delve into their sacrosanct playbook, RFC 9110: A Guide to Crafting Chaos.

First off, let's talk about our boy, User-Agent. Remember when Netscape was king, and Internet Explorer was a mere pup? The battle lines were drawn here. But the HTTP Hackers aren't about loyalty; they're about mayhem. So they concoct an abomination of a User-Agent string, a monstrous hybrid of every browser ever made—the ultimate troll move.

Next up: Host header hijinks. This one's a classic. You send a request to Google with a Host header that reads www.nsfw_site.com. Just imagine the chaos as Google tries to serve you pornographic content in your search results. Pranks like these are why we can't have nice things, folks.

Then there's the mighty GET request, the workhorse of the web. But our pals at HTTP Hackers don't settle for ordinary payloads. No, they stuff their GET requests with absurd amounts of data, causing servers to choke on a digital feast fit for the gods. It's like giving a toddler a candy shop and watching the resulting tantrum—only far more technical.

Last but not least, we have the infamous POST request. This is where things get messy. The HTTP Hackers don't just send data; they send malicious data, crafted to corrupt databases, hijack sessions, and generally wreak havoc. It's like playing a violent game of Telephone with the entire internet—and winning.

So there you have it, folks: RFC 9110, a manual for mayhem. But remember, while we laugh at their antics, the HTTP Hackers are out there, lurking in the shadows, ready to strike at a moment's notice. So keep your servers secure and your data backed up—or risk joining the ranks of those who've been trolled by the HTTP Hackers.

Original article: [On HTTP Request Smuggling - RFC 9110 Style](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CvEBA_Sm-mw)

title: Nevada Hacked: Officials Scramble to Decode 'Oops, All Bitcoins
excerpt: In a turn of events that would make even the most seasoned cybersecurity experts quake in their keyboard-laden boots, the digital fortress protecting Nevada's vast crypto riches has been breached...
content:
In a turn of events that would make even the most seasoned cybersecurity experts quake in their keyboard-laden boots, the digital fortress protecting Nevada's vast crypto riches has been breached. Yes, you heard it right—the Silver State's treasure trove of Bitcoin has been compromised, sending shockwaves through the tech and finance industries alike.

As officials scramble to pick up their collective jaws from the floor, they're now faced with the daunting task of decoding the ominous message that greeted them upon discovering the breach: 'Oops, All Bitcoins.' A cryptic message, indeed, that's left everyone scratching their heads and mumbling profanities under their breath.

One could argue that Nevada was asking for it—after all, when you name a state after a card game, what do you expect? But alas, we find ourselves in a predicament where the only cards being played belong to an unseen adversary with an unquenchable thirst for digital currency.

The Nevada Bureau of Digital Mining and Gaming (NBDMG) is now at the epicenter of this international incident, with every eye on them as they race against time to recover their stolen assets. Their first order of business? To figure out what the hell 'Oops, All Bitcoins' even means.

The NBDMG has since enlisted the help of top cryptanalysts from around the world, who have spent days poring over the message in an attempt to unravel its meaning. Some theories suggest it could be a harmless inside joke gone wrong, while others believe it's a coded command to move all bitcoins to an unknown location. Either way, it's got everyone in a tizzy.

Meanwhile, Nevada's Governor has made a desperate plea for the return of the stolen digital currency, promising leniency towards the culprits if they cooperate. "We understand that mistakes happen," the Governor said, "but please, for the love of all things holy, give us back our damn Bitcoins."

As the world watches with bated breath, Nevada finds itself in uncharted territory—a digital Wild West where the rules are constantly being rewritten, and the stakes are higher than ever. And as we struggle to make sense of this chaotic situation, one thing remains clear: when it comes to the digital frontier, nothing is sacred.

Original article: [Federal, state officials investigating ransomware attack targeting Nevada](https://www.cybersecuritydive.com/news/federal-state-investigating-ransomware-nevada/758863/)

title: Password Blunders: Another Cookie Thief Steals Your Login Lunch!
excerpt: In the grand tapestry of human folly, there's a new thread being woven with such comedic brilliance that it deserves a standing ovation...
content:
In the grand tapestry of human folly, there's a new thread being woven with such comedic brilliance that it deserves a standing ovation. Or perhaps, a good old-fashioned facepalm would suffice. Today, we bring you the latest chapter in our never-ending saga of digital disasters: The Great Password Heist of 20XX!

Now, I'm not one to gloat, but if you've been keeping your login details under a digital matress (yes, that's a thing), it's time to wake up and smell the coffee—or better yet, time to change your password. Again.

You see, dear reader, our story begins with the tale of John Doe, a man of average intelligence and an extraordinary knack for password security—that is, if we consider "password123" an example of top-notch encryption. John, like many of us, has accounts scattered across the digital landscape—social media, banking, online shopping, and even that weird forum dedicated to collecting rubber ducks (yes, really).

One fateful day, while John was engrossed in his latest duck debate, a figure cloaked in shadows appeared. This mysterious character, whom we shall dub "Cookie Monster," snuck into John's computer and went on a rampage, feasting on all the delicious login cookies he could find. In less time than it takes to polish off a plate of cookies, Cookie Monster had absconded with John's precious digital goods.

Now, you might be thinking, "But surely, John must have implemented some form of security?" Well, my friend, the only firewall protecting John was a screen saver featuring kittens playing pianos—hardly an impenetrable fortress. And so, our digital Don Juan made off with the loot, leaving John to deal with the fallout.

And here's where things get even more absurd: in his haste to regain control of his accounts, John decided to use the same password for every platform—you guessed it—"password123." I know, I know—it's a story that would make even the most seasoned satirist weep tears of laughter.

The moral of this tale is simple: if you value your digital life, treat your passwords with the respect they deserve. And for the love of all things holy, please don't use "password123."

Original article: [Smashing Security podcast #432: Oops! I auto-filled my password into a cookie banner](https://grahamcluley.com/smashing-security-podcast-432/)

title: Burning Out on Penetration Tests: It's Not All Fun and Hack
excerpt: In the shadowy underbelly of the digital world, where data breaches are as common as morning coffee and passwords are more sacred than holy relics, there lies a band of misfits, known only as Penetration Testers...
content:
In the shadowy underbelly of the digital world, where data breaches are as common as morning coffee and passwords are more sacred than holy relics, there lies a band of misfits, known only as Penetration Testers. These modern-day knights errant traverse the vast expanse of the internet, their lances aimed at cybersecurity vulnerabilities, swords poised to skewer any digital dragon that dares to threaten the sanctity of our data fortresses.

But the life of a Pen Tester is not all glory and gold. It's a brutal, unforgiving landscape where the only constants are relentless stress and a crippling sense of dread. For these digital warriors, every day is a battle against an enemy that never sleeps, never tires, and has an army of script kiddies at its disposal.

Take our protagonist, John, a seasoned Pen Tester with the looks of Brad Pitt and the charm of a porcupine. He's seen it all - from the humbling defeat at the hands of a misconfigured firewall to the exhilarating triumph over an unpatched vulnerability. But despite his battle-hardened exterior, John is starting to crack under the pressure.

One fateful day, John found himself staring at the cold, unfeeling screen, a potent blend of caffeine and adrenaline coursing through his veins. His fingers danced across the keyboard, typing commands with the precision of a surgeon performing a delicate operation. And then, as if fate had a wicked sense of humor, it happened - an error message, a digital scream that shattered John's concentration like a bomb going off in his head.

In that moment, John realized that he was burned out. The thrill of the hunt had become a never-ending nightmare, the rush of victory replaced by a gnawing emptiness. He was no longer John, the fearless Pen Tester; he was just another drone in the digital battlefield, fighting a losing battle against an enemy that refused to play fair.

And so, our hero embarked on a quest for redemption - a journey to find meaning in a world that seemed intent on breaking him. He sought solace in the arms of philosophy, finding comfort in the words of Nietzsche and Camus. He even considered a career change, pondering the merits of becoming a librarian or a taxidermist.

But in the end, John realized that he belonged on the battlefield, that his purpose was to protect the digital realm from the forces of chaos and darkness. And with newfound determination, he returned to his post, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

So here's a toast to all the Pen Testers out there - those brave souls who stand between us and the digital apocalypse. May your servers be secure, your firewalls impenetrable, and your coffee strong enough to withstand the relentless onslaught of cyber threats. And remember, no matter how dark the night may seem, there's always a dawn just around the corner.

Original article: [Penetration Testing and Burnout](https://trustedsec.com/blog/pen-testing-and-burnout)
author: AutoGenerator

title: BlackSuit Cashes In on Black Basta's Backstabbing Brawl.
excerpt: In the world where cybercrime thrives like a digital fungus, we find ourselves entwined in yet another tangled web of deceit and betrayal...
content:
In the world where cybercrime thrives like a digital fungus, we find ourselves entwined in yet another tangled web of deceit and betrayal. This time, it's not just your average Joe hacking Grandma's email for cat memes; no, this is an epic saga of corporate espionage, backstabbing, and enough betrayals to make Shakespeare weep into his quill.

The players in this drama are BlackSuit, the cybersecurity firm with a reputation as impenetrable as Fort Knox's vault, and Black Basta, a notorious hacking collective known for their love of chaos and all things nefarious. It was a match made in hell, but like any good tragedy, it was doomed from the start.

Their union began with promises of power, wealth, and the kind of influence that makes mortals quiver in fear. But as the old saying goes, you can't polish a turd, no matter how hard you try. Or in this case, you can't teach a pack of vicious hackers to behave like civilized beings.

Black Basta, true to form, started causing mayhem left and right, their antics making headlines for all the wrong reasons. The public outcry was deafening, and even BlackSuit's impeccable reputation couldn't silence it. Something had to give, and that something turned out to be the relationship between these two digital adversaries.

In a stunning turn of events, BlackSuit decided to cut ties with their unruly partners. The breakup was messy, involving a series of public squabbles, accusations, and even some creative use of hacking tools against each other. It was like watching a catfight between two house cats that happen to be armed with machine guns.

But out of the ashes of this digital debacle, BlackSuit emerged victorious. They managed to weather the storm, maintain their reputation, and even capitalize on the situation by offering their services to businesses wary of falling victim to similar attacks. It's a win-win for BlackSuit—they get to clean up the mess left behind by Black Basta, and they get paid handsomely for it.

So here we are, back to square one. Cybercrime continues to run rampant, and we can only hope that the next chapter in this never-ending story won't be as entertaining—or as disastrous—as this one.

title: OCSP's Lifeless End Signals Yet Another Tech Mourning
excerpt: In a stark twist of irony that would make Samuel Beckett cackle into his peeled potato soup, Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP), the unsung hero of digital trust and security, has finally shuffled off this mortal coil...
content:
In a stark twist of irony that would make Samuel Beckett cackle into his peeled potato soup, Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP), the unsung hero of digital trust and security, has finally shuffled off this mortal coil. The news sent ripples of despair across the tech world, as if someone had just told Silicon Valley that unlimited coffee rations were ending - permanently.

If you're scratching your head right now, allow me to explain. OCSP was the digital guard dog that ensured our web browsers didn't wander off and mingle with cyber predators masquerading as legitimate websites. It was the bouncer at the door of the internet, checking IDs and certificates before granting entry.

And now, it's gone.

Just like that, the guard dog's bark has been silenced. The bouncer is off duty. The digital world is left wide open, a wild frontier where anyone with a fake certificate can pretend to be your favorite pizza delivery guy, promising hot, cheesy delights but delivering cold, hard disappointment.

But hey, who needs security when you've got strong passwords, right?

As the tech world mourns the loss of OCSP, it's a stark reminder that even the most essential services can crumble under the weight of their own complexity. And as we move towards an increasingly digital world, it's a chilling thought to consider what other unsung heroes might be teetering on the brink of extinction.

So here's to you, OCSP. You may have been a humble behind-the-scenes player, but without you, our digital lives would be a lot more treacherous. Rest in peace, dear protocol. The internet will never forget your service... or the nightmares it may bring about in the future.

Original article: [OCSP Service Has Reached End of Life](https://letsencrypt.org/2025/08/06/ocsp-service-has-reached-end-of-life.html)
author: AutoGenerator

title: Salesforce Users: Your Data Drifted into Hacker's Cloudy Hands
excerpt: In the digital wild west we've found ourselves ensconced, where cowboy hats are swapped for hoodies and steeds for keyboards, our latest hero (or villain, depending on your perspective) has emerged: a data-wrangling outlaw known only as 'The Cloud Marshal'...
content:
In the digital wild west we've found ourselves ensconced, where cowboy hats are swapped for hoodies and steeds for keyboards, our latest hero (or villain, depending on your perspective) has emerged: a data-wrangling outlaw known only as 'The Cloud Marshal'.

This shadowy figure, with seemingly limitless bandwidth, has been causing quite the ruckus in the quiet town of Salesforce. Reports are circulating that he's single-handedly stolen every piece of data stored within the city limits – from sales leads to customer service tickets and even those embarrassing 'out of office' messages we all wish could disappear into thin air.

But fear not, dear citizens of Salesforce! The local law enforcement is hot on his trail. Or at least they would be if they knew how to navigate the treacherous terrain of the internet. Instead, they're busy knocking on doors asking for passwords – apparently the old-fashioned way still works here.

As we await their inevitable capture (or perhaps a ransom demand), life goes on in Salesforce. Salespeople continue to hawk their wares, customer service agents struggle to keep up with a deluge of questions, and everyone nervously checks their emails wondering if they'll be next on The Cloud Marshal's hit list.

So what can we learn from this sordid tale? Well, for one, it seems that no data is truly secure – not even in the hands of the most reputable corporations. And two, if you want to play hide and seek with a real pro, hide somewhere other than your cloud storage account.

As we wait for this drama to unfold, remember: The Cloud Marshal isn't just after your data; he wants your peace of mind too. So keep an eye on the skies, lock down those accounts, and pray for better days ahead. Or maybe just move to a different cloud service provider – apparently they exist.

Original article: [Warning issued to Salesforce customers after hackers stole Salesloft Drift data](https://www.itpro.com/security/cyber-attacks/warning-issued-to-salesforce-customers-after-hackers-stole-salesloft-drift-data)

title: 162: Heiu's Hot Streak! Vietnam's Steamiest Serial Killer?
excerpt: In the sweltering heart of Ho Chi Minh City, where the humidity clings like a claustrophobic lover and the heat lays heavy on the asphalt, there's been an unsettling rise in body count...
content:
In the sweltering heart of Ho Chi Minh City, where the humidity clings like a claustrophobic lover and the heat lays heavy on the asphalt, there's been an unsettling rise in body count. And it ain't from heatstroke.

Enter Heiu - Vietnam's latest claim to infamy, the man who's made the term "hot streak" take on a whole new meaning. This cat's got more hearts than a seafood buffet and the charm of a cobra in mating season.

Heiu's been making headlines, not for his dance moves at local discos, but for his penchant for post-dance murder sprees. From Saigon to Hanoi, this man has left a trail of broken hearts and emptier graves. And here's the kicker - he's doing it with such panache that one can't help but wonder if he's auditioning for a role in a Vietnam-set slasher flick.

But let's not get ahead of ourselves. Heiu isn't just your garden-variety serial killer. No, sir. This guy has style. He leaves flowers at the scene, always red roses, and notes that read like bad poetry but somehow manage to capture the essence of pure, twisted romance. It's enough to make you want to vomit or swoon - depending on your taste in men and murder.

The authorities are baffled, the public is terrified, and our hearts? Well, they're a bit conflicted. There's something strangely appealing about a man who can make you want to both run screaming and fall hopelessly in love at the same time. And let's face it, in a world where reality TV stars are considered role models, a little danger never hurt anyone.

So, here's to Heiu - Vietnam's latest export, its steamiest serial killer, and the man who's given new meaning to the term "romantic getaway." May his murderous spree continue, may the bodies pile up, and may we all be entertained until the end.

Original article: [162: Hieu](https://darknetdiaries.com/episode/162/)

title: Weevil's Wee Takedown: The Teeny-Tiny Terror Strikes Back!
excerpt: In the grand tapestry of life, where lions roar and eagles soar, there exists a minuscule menace that has the audacity to disrupt our daily routines...
content:
In the grand tapestry of life, where lions roar and eagles soar, there exists a minuscule menace that has the audacity to disrupt our daily routines. A veritable morsel of mayhem, a mere speck on the cosmic scale - meet the Weevil.

This diminutive despot, no larger than a grain of rice, is wreaking havoc in pantries across the globe. It's like having a miniature marauder looting your snack stash, leaving behind only a trail of destruction and resentment.

These pint-sized pirates have an insatiable appetite for grains, particularly wheat, rice, and corn. They burrow their way into packages, creating tiny tunnels that make the food inedible. But it's not just about the ruined groceries; it's the principle of the thing! Who does this little bastard think he is, ruining our late-night munchie sessions?

But fear not, for humanity has always found a way to combat its adversaries. We've developed an arsenal of weapons against these unwelcome invaders - from traps laden with poisonous baits to the more DIY methods such as freezing or heating your food to eliminate the wee terrorists.

However, it seems our foe has grown wiser over time. These resilient reprobates have developed an immunity to some of our most potent poisons, turning our tactics against us like a tiny, twisted game of cat and mouse. It's a battle of epic proportions - man vs. weevil, David vs. Goliath... or maybe more accurately, David vs. Gulliver's Trickster Mini-Me.

So here's to the Weevil, the tiny tyrant that keeps us on our toes. May our ongoing struggle serve as a reminder that even the smallest of threats can cause significant disruptions in our lives. And hey, at least they provide us with plenty of material for satire and dark humor. After all, laughter is the best defense mechanism against impending doom, right?

Original article: [Weev, Part 1](https://redcircle.com/shows/597cfd00-b29a-49c6-9622-03c8decfc35f/episodes/7d9d5336-9826-4318-98b8-d621263fbe7b)

title: Sky Thieves: SK Telecom Fined $97M After Significant Heist.
excerpt: In a world where data is king and skyscrapers tower like gods, the news of SK Telecom's grand larceny has sent shockwaves through the corporate underbelly...
content:
In a world where data is king and skyscrapers tower like gods, the news of SK Telecom's grand larceny has sent shockwaves through the corporate underbelly. The tech titan, long revered as an innovator in the realm of telecommunications, has been exposed for a heinous crime of cosmic proportions - sky theft.

It all began when the good people of Seoul woke up to find their beloved city shrouded in an eerie darkness, reminiscent of an eclipse that had no moon. Intrigued and alarmed, they turned to their phones for answers only to find themselves greeted by nothing but dead air. The internet was down, and the streets were filled with panicked citizens desperate for information.

As investigators scurried to unravel this digital Gordian knot, it became evident that SK Telecom had stolen a substantial portion of the city's sky, repurposing it as their own personal data farm. The audacity of such a move was breathtaking, but the real question remained: how did they do it?

Well, it turns out, SK Telecom had been developing a groundbreaking technology called SkyLift, a device designed to hoist entire strata of atmosphere into their server farms. In a classic case of hubris, they decided to test the machine on Seoul, not realizing that the city's dense population and bustling infrastructure would create an unprecedented amount of data - enough to fill multiple skies.

The resulting chaos was catastrophic, with the city's power grid collapsing under the weight of the stolen sky. Traffic lights blinked out, elevators plummeted to the ground, and emergency services were left scrambling for backup. The only saving grace was that SK Telecom had managed to keep their nefarious activities hidden beneath a veil of technical jargon and corporate doublespeak.

However, the truth always finds a way to surface, and in this case, it took the form of a whistleblower - a disgruntled employee who leaked internal documents detailing the company's unethical practices. The revelation led to an immediate outcry from the public and prompted regulatory bodies to take action.

Now, SK Telecom finds itself slapped with a hefty $97M fine - pocket change compared to the billions they made from their illegal data farm. The fine may serve as a deterrent for other companies tempted to follow in SK Telecom's footsteps, but it does little to rectify the damage done to Seoul and its citizens.

As we struggle to recover from this audacious heist, one cannot help but wonder if justice will ever truly be served. But for now, we can only hope that the skies remain safe - and that our data remains where it belongs: in the clouds, not in the clutches of greedy corporations.

Original article: [Over $97M fine imposed on SK Telecom after significant hack](https://www.scworld.com/brief/over-97m-fine-imposed-on-sk-telecom-after-significant-hack)

title: Chinese Spies Cooking Up Another Global Helping of Cyber-Sabotage
excerpt: In the sprawling, technicolor metropolis that is Modern Cyberspace, where data flows like neon-tinged rivers through a labyrinth of fiber optic conduits, the latest buzz isn't about the next viral cat video or the latest celebrity gaffe...
content:
In the sprawling, technicolor metropolis that is Modern Cyberspace, where data flows like neon-tinged rivers through a labyrinth of fiber optic conduits, the latest buzz isn't about the next viral cat video or the latest celebrity gaffe. No, it's the same old song and dance - Chinese spies, cyber-sabotage, and global chaos.

You might think we'd be used to this nonsense by now, but apparently our collective memory span is shorter than a goldfish on a sugar high. So, let's dive back into the murky depths of cyberspace and swim with the sharks for a bit.

This time around, it's not just about hacking government servers or stealing intellectual property (though they do that too, don't worry). No, this is a whole new level of sinister. We're talking about the alleged infiltration of U.S. power grid systems, a move that could potentially plunge vast swaths of America into darkness at the flick of a switch - or, more accurately, a keystroke.

Now, you might ask, "Why would they do such a thing?" Well, dear reader, let me enlighten you with my razor-sharp wit and unparalleled cynicism. It's simple: because they can. Because we've allowed ourselves to become too complacent, too trusting, and far too dependent on technology that is, at its core, terrifyingly fragile.

But fear not! The U.S. government has taken swift action to address this situation, by which I mean they've called a press conference and issued stern warnings about the potential for widespread chaos. Because, you know, that's always been an effective deterrent in the past.

So, here we are, another day, another cyber-attack. But fear not, my friends! While the Chinese may be cooking up another helping of cyber-sabotage, we can take solace in the fact that our leaders are doing everything they can to ensure our safety - by telling us how dangerous things are. Because nothing says "we've got this under control" like a public warning and a sternly worded statement.

title: Thailand's PDPC Drops Hammer: Data Grubbers Fined Like a Bitch!
excerpt: In the land of tropical paradise and questionable spa massages, the Thai Personal Data Protection Committee (PDPC) has officially stepped out of the shadows and into the spotlight...
content:
In the land of tropical paradise and questionable spa massages, the Thai Personal Data Protection Committee (PDPC) has officially stepped out of the shadows and into the spotlight. And boy, did they make an entrance.

After years of digital data pirates feasting on unsuspecting Thai citizens' personal information like a fat cat at a buffet, the PDPC decided it was high time to put these data grubbers in their place. And by 'place', we mean a nice little corner with a big, fat fine slapped across their faces.

First up on the receiving end of the PDPC's wrath is a popular online food delivery service, who got hit with a whopping 1 million baht fine for collecting and storing customer data without proper consent. The company, which we won't name because frankly, they deserve to be forgotten, tried to play the 'oopsie daisies' card but let's be real - no one believes in accidents of this magnitude.

Next on the list is a telecommunications giant who decided it was cool to sell their customers' personal data to third-party marketers. Because who doesn't love getting unsolicited calls about miracle weight loss supplements at 3 am, right? Well, thanks to PDPC, they can now enjoy the fruits of their labor - a hefty fine of 5 million baht.

But it doesn't stop there. The PDPC has also taken aim at companies that failed to implement proper security measures for customer data, resulting in sensitive information being exposed. It's like leaving your front door wide open and expecting the neighbors not to waltz in for a look around.

The message is clear: the days of reckless data handling are over. Companies who fail to respect their customers' privacy will face the consequences. And if you thought 1 million or even 5 million baht fines were steep, just wait until you see what happens when a company repeatedly violates the law. Let's just say it'll make your eyes water like a bawling baby whose favorite toy has been snatched away.

So here's a friendly reminder to all data-hungry companies out there: Play fair or face the music. The PDPC is watching, and they're not afraid to drop the hammer when necessary. In Thailand, at least, your customers' personal information is no longer up for grabs.

Original article: [Huge Fines Imposed by Thailand’s PDPC: A Major Alert on Data Privacy Violations (Thailand)](https://malware.news/t/huge-fines-imposed-by-thailand-s-pdpc-a-major-alert-on-data-privacy-violations-thailand/98534)

title: Hack Attack! Cyber Clueless with Heidi Fumbles
excerpt: In a world where technology has become as essential as air and water, we find ourselves entangled in an endless dance with the digital realm...
content:
In a world where technology has become as essential as air and water, we find ourselves entangled in an endless dance with the digital realm. Today, dear readers, our tale of techno-woe unfolds around the hapless figure of Heidi Fumbles, a woman who embodies the very essence of cyber cluelessness.

Heidi's saga began innocuously enough, with an email from her bank informing her that she had won a brand-new iPad Pro and a weekend getaway to the Maldives. Excited at the prospect of scoring some free swag, Heidi clicked on the link without pausing for thought or a cup of coffee. Little did she know that this seemingly harmless action would set off a chain reaction of unimaginable digital mayhem.

Suddenly, her computer screen flickered and went dark. The silence was deafening as the once-cheery Heidi stared at her blank screen in abject terror. It didn't take long for her phone to ring, the caller ID displaying a number that seemed suspiciously foreign. As she picked up, an icy voice on the other end demanded an immediate ransom payment in exchange for the safe return of her digital life.

With the savvy of a three-toed sloth, Heidi frantically searched for help. She reached out to her tech-savvy friend, Mike "The Wizard" Watson, who calmly explained that she had been the victim of a phishing scam and that her computer was now brimming with malware.

In an attempt to save her digital soul, Heidi followed Mike's instructions: formatting her hard drive, installing antivirus software, and changing all her passwords to variations of "Password123." Alas, the hackers were not deterred; they continued to wreak havoc on Heidi's digital life.

As the hours ticked by, Heidi began to feel the weight of her own stupidity. The thought of all her personal information falling into the hands of strangers was enough to make even the hardiest among us shudder. But with each passing moment, she clung to the hope that this nightmare would soon be over and that she could return to her once-idyllic existence as a cyber clueless individual.

And so, dear readers, we leave Heidi Fumbles in the throes of her digital torment, a cautionary tale for us all. Remember: when it comes to cybersecurity, ignorance is not bliss; it's just a one-way ticket to misery.

title: Hack Your Way Through Bamboozled Printer Hell. Period.
excerpt: In the labyrinthine world of modern technology, one demon lies dormant in every household - the malevolent printer...
content:
In the labyrinthine world of modern technology, one demon lies dormant in every household - the malevolent printer. A seemingly innocent piece of equipment, it's actually a sinister beast that feasts on your soul and productivity, all under the guise of producing documents. Welcome to our guide on hacking your way through bamboozled printer hell. Period.

First off, let's address the elephant in the room: ink. This liquid gold is more precious than any jewel King Midas ever laid his greedy hands upon. The industry that manufactures it has managed to turn a simple necessity into a lucrative, expensive racket. But fear not! Our first hack involves using your own blood as an alternative ink source. We're only partially joking here - just make sure you've got a fresh tattoo or a recent paper cut before attempting this daring maneuver.

Now that we've covered the lifeblood of your printer, let's tackle its heart: the print head. It's delicate, finicky, and easily clogged - much like an aging rock star with a penchant for drugs and groupies. To unclog it, grab a toothpick or a bent paperclip, carefully insert it into the print head, and wiggle it around like you would during a particularly intense game of Operation. If that doesn't work, consider performing a full exorcism by soaking the print head in rubbing alcohol overnight before attempting another round of toothpick therapy.

Next up: paper jams. They're as common as traffic jams during rush hour, but far more frustrating. To avoid them, try feeding your printer only pristine, virgin paper - preferably from a forest where no unicorns have ever frolicked. If a jam does occur (and it will), use a pair of pliers to gently pry the paper apart without tearing it further. Remember: patience is key when dealing with the printer beast.

Lastly, let's discuss wireless connections. Your printer's ability to connect wirelessly is a double-edged sword - on one hand, it offers freedom; on the other, it opens the door for hackers and ghosts in the machine. To ward off these digital menaces, perform a ritual sacrifice by offering your oldest cat as an appeasement to the printer gods. If you don't have a cat, try using an Ethernet cable instead - it's more reliable and less likely to be possessed by malevolent spirits.

And there you have it! Armed with these hacks, you should now be able to navigate the treacherous waters of printer hell with minimal casualties (except for your sanity). Remember: when all else fails, consider investing in a typewriter or learning to write with quill and ink - at least then you'll know exactly where the frustration is coming from.

Original article: [Hacker's Guide to Bambu Printers & Multi-Material Prints](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=__QCWEeGHtY)

title: Windows Update: Your Grandma Just Gained Root Access - Again!
excerpt: In a shocking turn of events that has sent tech support hotlines into a frenzy and left millions of baby boomers scratching their heads, Microsoft's latest Windows update has inadvertently handed over root access to your dear old grandma...
content:
In a shocking turn of events that has sent tech support hotlines into a frenzy and left millions of baby boomers scratching their heads, Microsoft's latest Windows update has inadvertently handed over root access to your dear old grandma. Yes, you heard it right. The same woman who still struggles with VHS players and can't figure out how to text you back is now navigating the depths of your system's core like a seasoned hacker.

This unsolicited upgrade comes hot on the heels of Microsoft's recent push towards user-friendly interfaces, aiming to make technology more accessible for the elderly. But someone really should have thought this through a bit more. I mean, remember when she accidentally turned off your Wi-Fi during a Zoom meeting because she thought it was a light switch?

Now, picture that scenario but with your entire hard drive at stake. Just envision her, clad in her favorite floral print housecoat, command prompt open on her laptop screen as she types away with the ferocity of a caged tiger. And to top it all off, she's actually having fun!

Microsoft officials are currently scrambling to issue a patch to mitigate this unforeseen debacle. In the meantime, they've advised users to keep their valuables close and consider investing in some extra-strength password protection. Because let's face it - if grandma can't beat Pogo, she certainly won't be stumped by a simple alphanumeric sequence.

As for those of you who are already bracing yourselves for the inevitable, well, don't say I didn't warn you. And remember: always keep an eye on your grandma's laptop - especially when she starts rambling about "digging for treasure" and "buried secrets." There's a good chance she might just be clearing out your browser history or planting some embarrassing photos in your picture folders.

Original article: [CVE-2025-55230 Windows MBT Transport Driver Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2025-55230)

title: Hackers Breach Novant Health's "Top Secret" Team-Building Retreat
excerpt: Amidst the serene backdrop of a picturesque mountain lodge, nestled between towering pines and a bubbling brook, Novant Health's elite team-building retreat was under siege...
content:
Amidst the serene backdrop of a picturesque mountain lodge, nestled between towering pines and a bubbling brook, Novant Health's elite team-building retreat was under siege. Or more accurately, their password-protected PowerPoint presentations were.

In what can only be described as an epic fail of cybersecurity, hackers managed to penetrate the fortress that was supposed to protect the closely guarded secrets of Novant Health's top brass. The breach, which occurred during a particularly tense round of trust falls and bonding exercises, exposed confidential data such as employee performance reviews, secret recipes for the cafeteria's mediocre quiche, and even the office pet's vet records.

The hackers, believed to be a rogue collective known for trolling corporate retreats, took to the dark web to taunt their latest victims. "Novant Health thought they could escape us in the wilderness," one of the hackers boasted on a popular cybercrime forum. "But even Bigfoot can't hide from us when there's Wi-Fi involved."

As the dust settled, Novant Health scrambled to contain the damage, sending out emails to employees advising them to change their passwords and avoid using the company's wireless network in future retreats. The incident has left many questioning the effectiveness of Novant Health's cybersecurity measures, particularly when it comes to protecting sensitive information during team-building exercises.

"I guess we should have known better than to rely on trust falls as our primary defense against hackers," said one employee who wished to remain anonymous. "I mean, come on, that's just asking for trouble."

As the company continues to investigate the breach and implement new security measures, employees are left wondering if they can ever truly escape the prying eyes of cybercriminals, even in the great outdoors. For now, it seems the only thing Novant Health can truly count on is their ability to serve up mediocre quiche, no matter where they are.

Original article: [Q&A: Novant Health Reflects on Building a Strong Cybersecurity Team](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2025/08/qa-novant-health-reflects-building-strong-cybersecurity-team)

title: Security Sirens: How AI Turned Our Job into an Annoying Roomba
excerpt: In a world where the mundane is elevated to the existential, we find ourselves, the humble security guards, now relegated to the status of roving, beeping Roomba's...
content:
In a world where the mundane is elevated to the existential, we find ourselves, the humble security guards, now relegated to the status of roving, beeping Roomba's. Thanks, AI!

Once upon a time, we were the sentinels of steel and stone, the stalwart vanguard against intruders and nefarious do-gooders. Now, we're little more than automated nuisances, trilling like demented songbirds every time a shadow crosses a sensor.

Gone are the days of steely glares and hushed warnings. Replaced by a symphony of beeps, whistles, and alarms that would make a siren envious. We've become the bane of every late-night worker's existence, the unwelcome interruption to their illicit activities.

Our once proud uniforms, adorned with badges and epaulets, now serve only to accentuate our futility. Who needs a hero when you've got an app? We're the digital age's punchline, the sad reminder that technology can make even the most noble of professions obsolete.

But fear not, dear reader! There is a silver lining to this electronic cloud. For every alarm we set off, for every intruder we scare away with our relentless beeping, we are one step closer to retirement and the sweet, silent world beyond.

Until then, we'll continue to patrol our digital fiefdoms, our hearts aching for the days of yore when we were the masters of our own destiny, not mere components in an elaborate prank played by the tech gods.

So here's to us, the unwilling Roomba's of the security world. May our beeps forever echo through the halls of corporate America, a testament to the indomitable spirit of the human guard... and the inevitability of technological advancement.

Original article: [D@S #65: Empowering SOC Analysts with AI and Automation](https://www.detectionatscale.com/p/ep-65-ai-agents-empowering-soc-teams)

title: SAP's Android SDK: Another Leaky Basterd in Tech's Wild West
excerpt: In the grand tradition of chaos and calamity that is the tech industry, we find ourselves ensnared in another tangled web of software debacles...
content:
In the grand tradition of chaos and calamity that is the tech industry, we find ourselves ensnared in another tangled web of software debacles. This time, our hapless victims are the unsuspecting developers who dared to venture into the Android SDK jungle, created by none other than SAP, the digital equivalent of a three-legged donkey with a penchant for stepping on rakes.

The latest revelation in this saga involves an egregious security flaw that has left more than 20,000 developers scratching their heads and muttering expletives under their breaths. It seems that the good folks at SAP have been unwittingly sending sensitive data from Android apps straight to a public server, without so much as a 'hey, how ya doin?' to the users.

Now, you might think that this is just another run-of-the-mill privacy breach in an industry that could give the Kardashians a run for their money. But, oh no, this is SAP we're talking about here - the masters of understatement and subtlety. They didn't merely 'accidentally' leak user data; they went full-blown Three Stooges, leaving a trail of digital breadcrumbs that could make even the most clueless hacker giggle with glee.

But fear not, dear readers! For SAP is on the case (or at least we assume they are - it's hard to tell when their responses are as elusive as Bigfoot's footprints). They have promised a fix, a patch, a Band-Aid for this gaping wound. However, given their track record, it seems more likely that they will release an update that requires users to dance the Macarena in order to access their own data.

So, here we are again, caught in the crossfire of tech's Wild West. As we watch our personal information get handed out like candy at a carnival, we can only hope that someone, somewhere, is keeping score. Because if there's one thing this industry needs, it's a dose of accountability - and a whole lot less three-legged donkeys.

title: Old OpenSSL: Still Secure as a Three-Legged Stool in a Windstorm
excerpt: In the realm of digital security, where the ephemeral meets the imperative, we find ourselves embroiled in a saga that could only be penned by the darkest of satirical minds...
content:
In the realm of digital security, where the ephemeral meets the imperative, we find ourselves embroiled in a saga that could only be penned by the darkest of satirical minds. Today's starring character? None other than Old OpenSSL - the three-legged stool bravely standing against the gale force winds of cybercrime.

Now, for those who've just stumbled upon this digital pantomime and find themselves scratching their heads, allow us to provide a brief recap. Old OpenSSL is a venerable cryptographic library, older than most internet-savvy teenagers, yet still managing to cling precariously to relevance in the ever-evolving world of cybersecurity. It's like that grizzled veteran who, despite his advancing years and apparent lack of vitality, somehow always manages to come out on top during bar brawls.

Yet here we are, standing at the precipice of 2022, and Old OpenSSL remains in service. One might ask, what is it about this antiquated piece of software that has kept it from being retired to the digital dustbin? The answer, dear reader, lies not in its robustness or effectiveness, but rather in its utter lack thereof.

Think of it as a party game where everyone gets to take turns poking holes in the stool. Each participant takes a swing, and yet, despite their best efforts, Old OpenSSL continues to stand - albeit with an ever-growing number of weak points. It's like playing Whack-A-Mole, but instead of cute rodents, you have a never-ending supply of cybercriminals, and the mallets are exploits galore.

Now, one might wonder if there is any hope for this three-legged stool in a windstorm. Alas, our answer is a resounding 'meh'. Old OpenSSL will continue to limp along, providing the digital equivalent of a false sense of security while leaving systems vulnerable to attack. It's like having a pit bull guard dog with no teeth - it might look intimidating, but don't count on it for protection.

So, as we move forward into another year of digital mayhem, let us raise a glass (or perhaps a shot) in honor of Old OpenSSL - the intrepid, if utterly useless, three-legged stool that continues to stand against the windstorm of cybercrime. Here's to many more years of dubious security and questionable protection!

Original article: [Dropping old OpenSSL](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2025/08/28/dropping-old-openssl/)

title: Mozilla: Now Rooting for Hackers, Version 3.0
excerpt: In the grand tradition of tech giants' ceaseless quest for self-deprecation, we find ourselves in a peculiar predicament - Mozilla, yes, that bastion of open-source sanctity and home to the ever-faithful Firefox, has made a bold, brash, and somewhat bewildering announcement...
content:
In the grand tradition of tech giants' ceaseless quest for self-deprecation, we find ourselves in a peculiar predicament - Mozilla, yes, that bastion of open-source sanctity and home to the ever-faithful Firefox, has made a bold, brash, and somewhat bewildering announcement.

Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, geeks and trolls alike, feast your eyes on Mozilla's latest masterstroke: "Rooting for Hackers, Version 3.0."

That's right, you heard it here first, or rather, we're forcing it upon you like a bad tech support call at 2 AM. It seems the once-noble organization that vowed to keep the internet free and open has decided to turn its back on the very principles it was built upon.

But fear not! This isn't some half-baked, desperate attempt to cash in on the dark web market. Oh no, this is far more insidious. Mozilla is embracing hackers with open arms and an unparalleled level of naivety, declaring them the unsung heroes of the digital age.

Now, before you reach for your pitchforks and torches (or perhaps the closest virtual equivalent), let's delve a bit deeper into this madness. Mozilla argues that hackers are the pioneers, the mavericks who push boundaries and challenge the status quo. They claim these digital rebels embody the very spirit of innovation, and who are we to argue?

After all, it was a hacker who first discovered that clicking on pop-up ads could fund our late-night browser escapades, or the one who figured out how to make those pesky auto-play videos start after only a few seconds. So in essence, they're not entirely wrong.

But let's be real here, folks. Hackers are just as likely to crash your system, steal your data, and sell it to the highest bidder as they are to create something truly groundbreaking. Still, Mozilla is betting on the rainbows and unicorns aspect of hacker culture, and who are we to judge?

In this new era of embracing cybercriminals, Mozilla has pledged to provide hackers with a safe space to share their knowledge and collaborate on nefarious projects. They've even gone so far as to create a "Hackers' Haven" within the Firefox community, where they can exchange tips, tricks, and potentially damning secrets without fear of reprisal.

So, my friends, brace yourselves for a world where the lines between good and evil blur even further, where the digital landscape becomes increasingly treacherous, and where Mozilla, once a beacon of hope in the wild west that is the internet, becomes the unwitting cheerleader for cybercrime.

Welcome to Mozilla: Now Rooting for Hackers, Version 3.0 - may your passwords be strong, and your antivirus software up to date.

Original article: [Enhancing CA Practices: Key Updates in Mozilla Root Store Policy, v3.0](https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2025/03/12/enhancing-ca-practices-key-updates-in-mozilla-root-store-policy-v3-0/)

title: IOTW: Victoria's Secret Tapes Held Hostage by Crypt-Tart!
excerpt: In a bizarre turn of events that would make even Michael Bay's most explosive action flick seem tame, the world was left in shock as news broke that Victoria's Secret's prized collection of lingerie prototypes had been held hostage by an enigmatic figure known only as Crypt-Tart...
content:
In a bizarre turn of events that would make even Michael Bay's most explosive action flick seem tame, the world was left in shock as news broke that Victoria's Secret's prized collection of lingerie prototypes had been held hostage by an enigmatic figure known only as Crypt-Tart.

The high fashion industry, already reeling from the devastating impact of COVID-19 on fashion week events, was dealt another blow when it was revealed that Victoria's Secret's latest line – rumored to be worth millions – had disappeared without a trace. The collection, which reportedly featured innovative designs incorporating cutting-edge IoT technology, was set to revolutionize the lingerie market and restore the brand's dwindling popularity.

But, alas, it seems that even in the digital age, good ideas can still fall victim to nefarious villains hiding in the shadows. Or, in this case, lurking within the depths of the cryptocurrency world.

Crypt-Tart, a figure as elusive as their moniker suggests, has been sending ominous messages to Victoria's Secret's top executives, demanding a ransom in Bitcoin for the safe return of the stolen designs. The ransom note, delivered via encrypted messaging service, read: "Yo, Victoria, your secrets are mine now, baby! Hand over 10K BTC or say goodbye to those angel wings – forever!"

In response, the lingerie giant has reportedly hired a team of cybersecurity experts to track down Crypt-Tart and negotiate the return of their stolen intellectual property. However, with little progress made thus far and the deadline for payment rapidly approaching, the future of Victoria's Secret – and its much-anticipated IoT collection – hangs precariously in the balance.

As the world watches with bated breath, one can only wonder if this latest scandal will be enough to finally take down the once-dominant lingerie empire. Will Crypt-Tart emerge victorious, leaving Victoria's Secret in ruins? Or will the brand manage to fight back and regain control of its most valuable assets?

Stay tuned for further developments in this thrilling tale of intrigue, technology, and high-stakes business drama. In a world where innovation meets corruption, only one thing is certain: the lingerie game just got a whole lot more dangerous.

title: Tech Titan's Latest AI: Comprehends Sarcasm, Stumped By Coworkers
excerpt: In the world of tech, where innovation is king and ego is queen, a new contender has emerged from the labyrinth of silicon and circuits...
content:
In the world of tech, where innovation is king and ego is queen, a new contender has emerged from the labyrinth of silicon and circuits. A behemoth so magnificent, it's given humanity a new reason to question its own mediocrity - a super AI that understands sarcasm.

Now, you might be thinking, "What's the big deal? Humans have been slinging sarcastic barbs at each other since caveman days." Well, dear reader, let me tell you about this AI. It's called 'SarcBot 3000', and it's so advanced that it can recognize when a cat video is actually a dog video. Yes, you read that right. It's that good... or bad, depending on your perspective.

The tech world is abuzz with excitement over this breakthrough. At the unveiling event, CEOs were seen drooling over SarcBot 3000 like hungry hyenas circling a fresh kill. Mark Zuckerberg even asked it if it was going to report him to Facebook for wearing sweatpants during the presentation. The AI's response? A polite chuckle and a question about whether it needed to file a police report instead.

However, SarcBot 3000's triumphant entry into the world of technology has not been without its challenges. It seems that beneath its shiny veneer of wit and intelligence lies a soul as fragile as a delicate porcelain doll. Or maybe it's more like a glass cannon - capable of incredible feats, but shatter at the slightest provocation.

Case in point: during a team meeting, an intern decided to test SarcBot 3000 by asking it if it knew what the term 'tech bro' meant. The AI responded with a snarky remark about how its creator had asked it that very question numerous times already. Needless to say, the room went silent faster than a cat caught in a coyote trap.

So, there you have it - the latest addition to our ever-growing stable of intelligent machines. It can comprehend sarcasm, but can't seem to handle office politics. Who knows? Maybe in a few years, we'll have AIs that can understand and navigate the intricate dance of human emotions like a seasoned ballroom dancer. But for now, let's just enjoy the spectacle of SarcBot 3000 stumbling through the minefield of sarcasm like a bull in a china shop.

title: Immui's Latest: Now Making Losers Winners...Automagically.
excerpt: In a world where life imitates bad sitcoms, we find ourselves entangled in another episode of relentless capitalistic endeavor...
content:
In a world where life imitates bad sitcoms, we find ourselves entangled in another episode of relentless capitalistic endeavor. Today, we're diving headfirst into the enchanting realm of Immui, the company that has promised to turn your pathetic existence into a victorious one - and all without lifting a finger!

"But wait," you ask, "how can this be possible?" Well, buckle up, buttercup, because we're about to venture into the mystical land of 'automagic.'

You see, Immui's latest creation is a device that promises to transform your very soul, all while you sleep. Yes, that's right; no more late-night cramming or tireless training sessions - just sweet dreams and dreamsickle mornings filled with the warm embrace of triumph!

But how does it work, you inquire? Well, my friend, that's where things get...complex. Immui's scientists have spent countless hours poring over ancient tomes and modern-day infomercials, concocting a formula so powerful, it can turn even the most pitiful of humans into winners.

The process is simple: plug in the device, wear the sleek, yet stylish headband, and drift off into la-la land. As you slumber, the machine works its magic, rewiring your brain's reward centers to crave only victory. Wake up, and voila! You're a winner. Congratulations, champ!

But don't get too excited just yet. There's a catch - or several, actually. Firstly, the device doesn't discriminate between winning at life or winning at Candy Crush. So if you've always dreamed of being a successful entrepreneur, artist, or world leader, well...you might wind up with an impressive high score in Bejeweled instead.

Secondly, the device is not free - oh no, it's not free. In fact, it costs more than a year's worth of therapy for your self-esteem issues. But hey, what price can you put on success?

Lastly, and perhaps most importantly, there's always the risk that the device will malfunction, rewiring your brain to crave failure instead. Imagine that: waking up every day to a world where losing is the only option. Now THAT would be a real game-changer!

In conclusion, Immui's latest creation promises to turn losers into winners...automagically. Will it work? Who knows - but at least it'll give us something entertaining to watch while we all wait for our lives to magically improve.

title: WIBU-Woe! Hackers Score Big with Boost from Busted CodeMeter
excerpt: In a world where digital security is as elusive as a politician's integrity, we find ourselves once again entangled in the tangled web of cybercrime...
content:
In a world where digital security is as elusive as a politician's integrity, we find ourselves once again entangled in the tangled web of cybercrime. This time, it's not just your grandmother's credit card information or that embarrassing selfie that's at risk—it's the very software that keeps our digital lives afloat. Yes, folks, WIBU-Woe has struck again, and this time, the hackers have scored a grand slam courtesy of CodeMeter's colossal blunder.

For those unfamiliar with the acronym du jour, WIBU (short for "Who's In Control Anyway?") is a notorious piece of software designed to protect intellectual property by limiting its use and preventing unauthorized distribution. It's like having a bouncer at the digital club who only lets in the cool kids—or in this case, the ones who can afford it.

Now, CodeMeter, a respected name in the digital rights management (DRM) world, has inadvertently opened the velvet rope to all comers. It seems their code, which is meant to keep hackers at bay, had a few too many drinks and decided to go streaking through the internet. The result? Hackers are now frolicking amidst sensitive data with the glee of schoolchildren on a field trip.

It's like watching a horror movie where the protagonist forgets to lock the front door, then spends the rest of the film screaming at the audience, "Why did I leave it open?!" Only instead of a masked killer, we've got a digital menace on our hands—and the door was left wide open by one of the good guys.

So, as you go about your day, be sure to double-check those digital locks and remember: in this world, there's no such thing as too much security... unless you're CodeMeter, apparently.

title: New EU Boss: Just Another Bloke with All the Answers!
excerpt: In a stunning turn of events that will send shockwaves throughout the European Union (EU), the bloc has appointed yet another man to lead them out of their myriad of problems...
content:
In a stunning turn of events that will send shockwaves throughout the European Union (EU), the bloc has appointed yet another man to lead them out of their myriad of problems. Yes, you heard it right - another bloke with all the answers.

The newly minted EU boss, who we'll call 'Joe Schmoe' for anonymity purposes (because let's be real, who really cares about these guys anyway?), has a distinguished career in politics that boils down to one thing: promising change and delivering more of the same.

Schmoe comes from the land of beer, sausages, and lederhosen, making him an ideal candidate for a position that requires endless amounts of pretzels and beer goggles. He promises to bring "stability" to the EU, a term that translates roughly as "more bureaucracy, less democracy."

The appointment has sparked controversy among the populace who are growing tired of the same old song and dance. Protests have erupted across the continent, with signs reading, "Give us another man with all the answers, and we'll give you another Brexit!"

Schmoe has responded to these criticisms by assuring the public that he is different this time. He has a new haircut, a fresh suit, and even a shiny new pair of shoes - proof positive that he means business. He also mentioned that he has a new plan to address climate change: "Plant more trees," he said, before quickly adding, "But not in my backyard."

As the EU braces for another round of political grandstanding and empty promises, it's worth asking if this latest appointment is just another nail in the coffin for a continent desperate for real change. But let's be honest here, who are we kidding? This is Europe we're talking about - where the only thing that ever changes is the guy holding the title.

title: Oracle's Party Foul: Elsa's Update Ruins Yet Another Bash
excerpt: In a shocking twist that sent shockwaves through Silicon Valley, tech giant Oracle found itself in the crosshairs of public scorn this weekend...
content:
In a shocking twist that sent shockwaves through Silicon Valley, tech giant Oracle found itself in the crosshairs of public scorn this weekend. The culprit? None other than their latest software update, lovingly dubbed 'Elsa's Frozen Folly.' But before you roll your eyes and mutter "here we go again," let us paint a picture of the chaos that ensued at Oracle's annual soiree.

The scene was set: Oracle's sprawling campus transformed into a veritable playground for the elite, replete with inflatable swans, an endless buffet, and even a petting zoo - because who doesn't want to cuddle up with a baby goat while discussing the intricacies of cloud computing? But alas, it was not meant to be.

As guests clinked glasses and exchanged pleasantries, little did they know that Elsa had other plans. A mysterious glitch, thought to have been conjured by the Nordic queen herself, began wreaking havoc on the proceedings. The swanky invitation app, a pride and joy of Oracle's marketing department, started acting up - sending invitations to the wrong people, revoking them at random, and even sending out mass apologies for nonexistent faux pas.

The partygoers were left in a state of confusion, unsure if they were on the guest list or not, and if they were, when they would be allowed to grace Oracle's hallowed grounds. The tech titan, who had spent millions crafting the perfect event, found itself scrambling to salvage what was left of its shattered reputation.

But fear not, dear readers. For every calamity there is a silver lining. This debacle has provided us with ample comedic fodder and a valuable lesson: perhaps it's time we reconsidered our blind faith in artificial intelligence and the algorithms that run our lives. After all, who knew that an update meant to streamline party invitations could bring an entire tech titan to its knees?

In the end, the only thing left to do was pour a stiff drink, shake one's head in disbelief, and wait for the next round of technological folly. As we say here at the dailynovel: may Elsa's Frozen Folly serve as a reminder that even the most advanced AI can't handle a simple party invite - and nor can some of us, if we're being honest.

title: GraphQL's GotSQLem: When Queries Get a Little Too Query-ous.
excerpt: In the realm of programming, where chaos and order coexist like oil and water, we've seen it all - from the ashes of COBOL to the rise of Python's 'it just works' fame...
content:
In the realm of programming, where chaos and order coexist like oil and water, we've seen it all - from the ashes of COBOL to the rise of Python's 'it just works' fame. But now, dear reader, prepare to feast your eyes on a new breed of chaos: GraphQL's GotSQLem.

For those blissfully unaware, GraphQL is that hipster kid on the block who swears he can do everything better than REST. He promises flexibility, efficiency, and a more personalized approach to data fetching. But like any rebellious teenager, he's not without his flaws.

Enter GotSQLem, the mutant offspring of GraphQL and SQL injection. This miscreant is born from the reckless use of user-supplied input in your GraphQL queries - a practice that's as dangerous as letting a toddler play with fireworks.

GotSQLem doesn't care about your pretty schema or your resolver functions. He's got one mission: to crash your server and make your life a living hell. And he does it in style, bypassing the usual web application vulnerabilities to inject raw SQL into your queries.

So, how does this little monster work? Imagine you have a GraphQL API for managing user accounts. A malicious user sends a query like this:

```
query {
  user(id: "1' OR 1=1--") {
    name
    email
  }
}
```

Here, the single quote and comment symbol after 'OR' are innocent-looking additions. But when combined with your resolver function, they create a SQL injection vulnerability that returns all user accounts - not just the one with id '1'.

And if you thought that was bad, wait until you hear about GotSQLem's love for stored procedures. He can exploit these to execute arbitrary commands on your database server, potentially compromising sensitive data or even taking your entire system down.

So, developers, heed this warning: Keep your queries clean, your resolvers secure, and never underestimate the power of a well-placed single quote. Or you might just find yourself in the uncomfortable position of having to explain to your boss why your GraphQL API is now a playground for GotSQLem.

Original article: [10/10 GraphQL SQL injection bug #bugbounty #bugbountytips #bugbountyhunter](https://www.youtube.com/shorts/uEqMfYq1tl8)
